This Committee was asked to report to the Council, which in turn would present its conclusions to the Second Assembly."The Council at its meeting in Geneva of December 17th, 1920, fixed March 31st, 1921. as the date of the termination of the period within which additional amendments might be submitted by a Member of the League; and the Secretary-General so informed the Members of the League by a circular letter dated December 28th, 1920.At its meeting in Paris of February 21st, 1921, the Council adopted a Resolu-tion providing for the appointment of a Committee of 11 Members, which was asked to examine the proposed amendments to the Covenant and certain related matters which had been submitted by the Assembly to the Committee,-together with any other proposals concerning- amendments of the Covenant which might be submitted by any Member of the League on or before March*3ist, 1921, the date fixed by the Council. CONSIDERATION DES DIFFERENTES PROPOSITIONS.ARTICLE I DU PACTE.Admission des Etats.La Commission a eu a examiner la proposition faite par S. E. M, Pueyrredon, au nom de la Delegation argentine a 1'Assemblee, le 4 decembrei920, ainsi formulee:(( Que tous les Etats souverains reconnus par la Communaute internationale soient admis a faire partie de la Societe des Nations, de telle facon que leur non incorporation soit le resultat d'une decision volontaire de leur part, bEvidemment, cette proposition envisage une modification de 1'Article I du Pacte et pour 1'inserer necessiterait qu'on en arretat la redaction, car le texte definitif n'en a pas ete formule. Elle ne mentionne, par exemple, que les Etats, et laisse de cote les dominions et les colonies. Dans une modification de 1'article 1, ces derniers devraient egalement etre pris en consideration. La propo-sition parle aussi d'Etats a souverains w, et Ton se demande si cette expression devrait entrer dans le Pacte qui jusqulci ne s'en est pas servi.Mais ce sont la des observations juridiques qui n'ont qu'une importance second-daire par comparaison avec le principe propose. Ce principe, le Gouvernement argen-tin l'a appuye dans sa lettre de 1'argumentation suivante:k La force de la Societe des Nations reside dans Incorporation du plus grandnombre d'Etats; moins elle en comptera en dehors de sa loi, plus nombreuxseront les Membres soumis a sa discipline et a l'accomplissement des devoirsque la Societe impose, island Commission partage le sentiment exprime dans cette phrase, qui ne saurait etre plus nette ni plus convaincante, et qui fait honneur aux vues du Gouvernement argentin et de ses Delegues.tSi toutefois la Commission n'exprime pas une opinion definitive sur 1'amen-dement propose, c'est qu'elle a juge que la portee de la modification est de nature si fondamentale, qu'il n'appartient pas a une Commission de se pronon-cer a ce sujet. En effet, la proposition comporte plus qu'un amendement au Pacte. Elle implique un changement fondamental dans la nature meme de la Societe des Nations actuelle. Les Membres de cette Societe l'ont formee et y ont adhere en se basant sur 1'article 1, tel qu'il est redige, c'est-a-dire dans 1'hypothese qu'ils auront le droit de voter sur 1'admission d'autres Membres, et d'apprecier 1'efncacite des garanties par eux offertes. Or, la proposition argentine tend precisement a modifier ce principe fondamental, en introduisant 1'idee de 1'admission automatique.Dans ces circonstances, la Commission a juge qu'il appartiendrait eventuelle-ment a 1'Assemblee, oil se trouveront reunis les Delegues des Membres memes de la Societe, de discuter cette question. CONSIDERATION OF THE VARIOUS PROPOSALS FOR THIS ARTICLE ONLY.ARTICLE i OF THE COVENANT.Admission of States.The Committee has had to examine the proposal put forward by H. E. M. Pueyr-redon (on behalf of the Argentine Delegation at the Assembly) on December 4th, 1920, which reads as follows: "That all sovereign States recognised by the community of nations beadmitted to join the League of Nations in such a manner that if they do not become Members of the League, this can only be the result of a voluntarydecision on their part. "This proposal obviously entails a modification of Article I of the Covenant, and in order to effect such a modification it would be necessary to amend the word-ing of the proposal, which was not drawn up as a final text. It makes no mention, for instance, of dominions and colonies, and refers merely to States. In any modification of Article I dominious and colonies must also be considered. The proposal also speaks of " sovereign " States, and the question arises whether this expression should be used in the Covenant, which hitherto has not employed such an expression.But these are legal technicalities which are only of secondary importance when compared with the principle which has been suggested. The Argentine Go-vernment has in its letter supported this principle by the following argument: " The strength of the League of Nations depends on its including thegreatest possible number of States; the fewer the States outside it, the greaterwill be the number of the Members pledged to carry out its discipline and to perform the duties which it imposes. "The Committee shares these views; they could not have been expressed in a manner more clear and more convincing. The Committee respects the opinions of the Argentine Government and of its Delegates.If the Committee has not expressed a definite opinion with regard to the pro-posed amendment, the reason lies in the fact that it considers that the scope of the modification implied is of so drastic a nature that it does not fall within the compe-tence of a Committee like the present one to give its views on the subject. The proposal indeed implies more than an amendment of the Covenant. It entails a drastic change in the very nature of the present League of Nations. The Members of this League, in creating it and in adhering to it, have based their action on Article I as at present drafted; that is to say, on the hypothesis that they will have the right of voting on the question of the admission of new Members and of estimating the efficacy of the guarantees which they offer. But the Argentine proposal has a direct tendency to modify this fundamental principle by introducing the idea of automatic admission.In these circumstances the Committee is of the opinion that this question is one which should be discussed in due time by the Assembly, where the Delegates of all the Members of the League will meet together. This principle applies equally, although with less importance, to States of a very small area, since every State constitutes a mo-ral entity whose susceptibilities and critical spirit should be respected. Moreover, the true object of the League, the development of co-operation among Nations with a view to guaranteeing peace and security, would be more readily attained if a certain class of States, even States of secondary importance, were not excluded.(b) There remains, therefore, only the question of the form which their attachment to the League should take. The recommendation of December 17th, 1920, has excluded in advance the possibility of admitting them as ordinary Members. Some other forms must, therefore, be found. It traces its origin to the fact, which has proved historically true, that a requirement of unanimity for all resolutions, without exception, often constitutes a serious hindrance to the practical working of institutions. Certain questions, moreover, have been removed by the Covenant itself from the category of those for which unanimity is required, among them, questions of procedure (Article 5, paragraph 2), the admission of new Members (Article 1, paragraph 2) and, finally, the adoption of amendments to the Covenant (Article 26). The resolutions adopted by the Council or the Assembly take two very different forms: sometimes the form of decisions properly so-called, sometimes theform of simple recommendations. This innovation would thus provide a world-wide system of commissions, which would necessitate the insti-tution by the Secretary-General of the League of Nations of a complete service of registration and communication.The Swedish amendment follows the lines of the Norwegian amendment, but only in so far as it constitutes commissions solely for conciliation; it does not go so far as to entrust them with arbitration. It prefers to leave arbitration to the Permanent Court of The Hague; the procedure proposed is therefore simpler.The Danish Government collaborated in the work, and entirely approves the principles on which these proposals are based. It has not associated itself officially with them because it hopes that a more thorough examination of the question will make it possible to bring forward a more practical and less complicated solu-tion.It must be noted here that the amendments were proposed in July, 1919. The following is a summary of the reasons for these amendments: " The investigation of international disputes should be undertaken in the first place by commissions previously appointed, consisting of an impartial presi-dent and of an equal number of members to be nominated by the parties to the dispute. SUMMARY OF THE FIRST REPORT OF THE COMMITTEEON AMENDMENTS,At the conclusion of the Committee's work it would appear desirable to sum-marise the results which it has arrived at in the course of its discussions on the questions with which it has had to deal. Taken as a whole, the proposals submitted in this Report would appear to mark an interesting evolution in the development of the League of Nations. While the fundamental principles of the Covenant have, by the general concensus of opinion, been found both equitable and well-founded, several modifications which do not constitute any transformation of the League's organisa-tion, but which are merely an adaptation to meet the circumstances of the day, have been added to the fabric of the League.If the proposals contained in this Report are adopted by the next Assembly, it can be said with truth that the League of Nations is aware of the necessity of avoiding the dangers of rigidity and of conservatism; and it will embark upon a course of pru-dent and gradual evolution.The proposals of the Committee allude in turn to the composition of the League of Nations, to its rights and duties, to its constitution and its organisation, and to the obligations of its Members.I. Composition,In accordance with the wish expressed by the Assembly, the Committee has sought a formula which would allow the participation in the work of the League of States which on account of their small size could not be admitted as ordinary Mem-bers.The Committee believes that it has found satisfactory solutions and has referred to these in its Report on Article i. It leaves a choice between three forms of affilia-tion: the system of direct association without the right of voting; the system of representation by an ordinary Member; and the system of granting to these States all the rights of Membership, but only for cases in which their own interests are involved.It may be hoped that by one or more of these methods the League will be in a position to extend its sphere of action to other political units which hitherto have not been able to take part in its work.The Argentine proposal for the admission of all States in such a manner that, if they do not become Members of the League, this can only be the result of a vo-luntary decision on their part a proposal supported by certain reasons with which the Committee fully sympathises has been considered to present the character of a fundamental modification of the Covenant; in any case it is a question which only the plenary Assembly can discuss.II.
